intro: Comanthera squarrosa var. elatior, commonly known as the desert morning glory, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its hairy, branched stems and heart-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine pubescence. The plant produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from pale blue to deep violet, typically blooming in the early morning. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sunlight, adapting well to harsh desert conditions. Its botanical features make it a distinctive and resilient species within the Convolvulaceae family.
